properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Buckeye Partners Transload Facility

2400 Michigan Street, Hammond, IN 46320
properties.EPA: This is a pipeline-to-train operation. It originates crude-by-rail shipments to refineries seeking the price discounts of Bakken and Tar Sands oil. As the corporation explained in 2013: "Western Canadian and Bakken crude oil expected to be transported via pipeline into Chicago Complex for ultimate delivery to unit-train facilities on the East, Gulf, and West Coasts." (source)
properties.website:
The new railcar loader can be seen in situ with the spyglass (just zoom in close). Here's the technical description:
"A 24-spot railcar loading rack, constructed in 2011, and approved in 2013 for modification, designed to load/offload petroleum product in up to six (6) railcars at a time through an available twelve (12) loading arms. The railcars are 30,000 gallons per car with a total rack capacity of 180,000 gallons per hour. The loading racks emissions will be controlled by two (2) vapor combustion units, identified as two VCU2 and three VCU3, with a natural gas-fuel pilot flame rated at 0.045 MMBtu/hr, as well as a vac assist for crude oil loading." (source).
properties.Notes: Link to company website.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Bakken Oil Express, Dickinson, ND
properties.Notes: This terminal is connected to gathering pipelines and also has 22 truck unloading stations. They have 640,000 barrels of storage and 4 loop tracks, which means they can load two unit trains simultaneously. Projected maximum capacity is 200,000 bpd.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Tesoro / BakkenLink Rail Hub, Fryburg, ND
properties.website: Press article on Tesoro's recent acquisition of the site here.
properties.Notes: They have a pipeline that connects to several gathering systems and a 657,000 barrel storage facility so they can pump 154,000 barrels a day of highly explosive crude into a bomb train headed near you.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Global Partners / Basin Transload (aka Zap Terminal), Beulah, ND
properties.Notes: The place has 280,000 barrels of storage capacity and they can ship 60,000 barrels a day.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Crestwood Midstream / COLT Hub, Epping, ND
properties.Notes:
It was built by a company called Rangeland: "With 720 MBbl of working capacity tankage (six 120 MBbl tanks), space for additional tanks (120 MBbl or larger), eight truck bays, and two 8,700 foot rail loops, COLT accommodates large 120-car unit trains and, at the time of its sale to Inergy Midstream, L.P. was capable of moving more than 120 MBbl/d by rail" (source here).
MBbl/d means "thousand barrels a day" in oilspeak; they are now up to 160,000 MBl/d of loading capacity, which definitely makes this a big one.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Global Partners / Basin Transload Columbus (aka Stampede) Terminal, Columbus, ND
properties.Image: Basin Transload supervisors honored by DoD
properties.Notes: A major oil logistics firm, Global Partners, bought this site and another one further south. Now they send a rolling stream of explosive oil to the East Coast by Canadian Pacific, without any change of company and locomotive in Chicago. As the business press reports: "In August 2012 Global completed a 100 Mb/d crude rail storage facility at the Basin Transload Stampede ND rail loading facility. In October 2012 Global acquired a 60 percent interest in Basin Transload including the Stampede terminal and the Zap rail loading terminal at Beulah, ND. Stampede can load 120 car trains at present at a rate of 80 Mb/d [that means 80,000 barrels a day]. The terminal will have a link to the Tesoro Pipeline in 2013. The major advantage of the Stampede terminal is the direct 'single-haul' trip to Albany, NY that takes 10 days round trip." (source here)

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

NGL Energy / High Sierra, Donnybrook, ND
properties.Image: --THIS PLACE IS TOO LOST FOR A PICTURE---
properties.Notes: It seems they only do 10,000 barrels a day.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Enbridge Berthold, Berthold, ND
properties.Notes: The 80,000 b/d rail facility also has a tank farm that's the departure point to the Enbridge mainline going to Superior, Wisconsin

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Plains All American / Manitou Rail Facility, Ross, ND
properties.Notes: The terminal has 150,000 barrels storage and the unit trainloader can do 65,000 barrels a day - but in early 2016 this site was reported closed, due to the collapse in demand from East Coast refineries which have switched back to overseas oil (source here). Industry operators now expect wildly fluctuating demand from the refineries as they shift capriciously between global producers.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Paradigm Midstream / Mountrail Terminal, Palermo, ND
properties.Notes: It's hard to determine the status of this one...

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Musket Terminal, Dickinson, ND
properties.Notes: "The Dickinson terminal is a small 10 Mb/d manifest truck to rail facility on the Southern BNSF line in Stark County that is also used by High Sierra Energy LP." (source here)

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Musket Terminal, Dore, ND
properties.Notes: "Originally the Dore terminal had only 10 Mb/d capacity but in 2012 it was upgraded to a 60 Mb/d unit train facility with 90 MBbl of storage. The Dore terminal receives crude from trucks as well as the Continental Oil Banner pipeline gathering system." (source here)

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Northstar Transloading, Fairview, ND
properties.Notes: They can unload 12 trucks at once, store 515,000 barrels of oil and pump 180,000 barrels a day onto unit and manifest trains. Manifest means it's shorter, like 40 cars that get mixed in with other things, unit is your typical 100+ cars of potential fireball.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Pioneer Terminal, New Town, ND
properties.Notes: From the website: "Dakota Plains crude oil operations are based around two 8,500 foot loop tracks each capable of 120 car unit trains, 180,000 barrels of crude oil storage, a high speed loading facility that can accommodate 10 rail cars simultaneously, two active gathering system pipelines and transfer stations to receive crude oil from 10 trucks simultaneously." They were hoping to do 80,000 barrels a day, plus frac sand, but that was in 2015 when the bottom was just falling out...

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

North Dakota Port Services / Port of Minot, Minot, ND
properties.Notes: "As originally planned, truck containers with products from Asia being shipped by rail to markets in the eastern U.S. would be loaded with agricultural products at NDPS rather than being sent back empty overseas. 'We discovered that a lot of that inbound freight to the Bakken was coming from Asia across the water via container,' [port CEO] Johnson explains. 'We made a proposal to our ocean carriers and the operators to utilize that container box by getting it off the train, off-loaded, inspected, cleaned up, reloaded with our ag products and sent back.'" (source here)

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Red River Terminal, Williston, ND
properties.Notes: It's an oil-services company adjacent to a traditional railyard that can also load 10,000 barrels a day - just a drop in the bucket of the Bakken oil industry. But the presence of drilling chemicals turned a traditional warehouse fire into a real inferno. (LA Times article here)

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Savage Terminal, Trenton, ND
properties.Notes: Here's what they said in 2014: "The Savage terminal in Trenton, ND, provides truck dispatch and transportation, unit train loading, single car transloading, and car storage for crude-by-rail shippers. Today, in the Williston Basin, Savage has the capacity to truck over 10,000 barrels per day today, and will add an additional 10,000 barrels per day capacity by February. The terminal can transload over 100,000 barrels of crude each day onto unit trains, with track capacity to hold up to two unit trains at the facility simultaneously, and has storage capacity of over 50 rail cars for crude-by-rail shippers. Savage currently has six crude receiving truck bays and 290,000 barrels of tankage with expansions underway that will increase the capacity of tank storage, truck receiving and outbound unit train loading." (source here)

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

EOG Resources / Stanley, ND
properties.Notes: The builder of the terminal, Wilson and Co., writes this: "The facility was designed to load 60,000 barrels of crude oil per day into one 100-car unit train, where it is transported to Oklahoma and other points south for refining. The crude oil is supplied to multiple storage tanks through a pipeline installed by EOG/Pecan Pipeline and by on-site truck unloading facilities. Loading operations are completed through an elevated rail side safety platform allowing 14 cars to be loaded simultaneously." (source here).

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Tioga Rail Terminal, Tioga, ND
properties.Notes: It can load two unit trains a day for a max capacity of 140,000 barrels a day.

properties.Name:
Crude-by-Rail

Plains ll American / Van Hook Crude Terminal, New Town, ND
properties.Notes: "The Van Hook Crude Terminal received oil by truck in New Town, ND, has capacity for 208 rail cars, and can move as much as 65,000 b/d. There is also 12,000 bbls of storage onsite. The terminal is serviced by Canadian Pacific Railroad. Most of the crude moving from the terminal ends up in St. James, LA, where the facility can handle 300 loaded railcars at one time or 130,000 b/d. The St. James Rail Terminal also ties into several pipelines, including one owned by PAA." (source here)) HOWEVER, activity at this site has slowed almost to zero as East Coast refineries switch back to imported crude (source here).
